results.title: The Shape of ships to come
results.creator_credit: Don Scheldrup, Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
A look at the guided missile frigate HMAS Adelaide, a new breed of ship in the destroyer class. It is the first Australian warship to be fitted with gas turbine engines, to have helicopter carrying capabilities and to be equipped with the over horizon missile ‘Harpoon’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Scheldrup, Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations

results.title: Malaria: the recurring enemy
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Department of Defence Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
Malaria has again become a major world health problem. Strains of malaria parasite have been resistant to drugs and species of anopheles mosquito have developed a tolerance for insecticides. Although research is being carried out aimed at defeating the disease, it still poses a threat to some areas of Australia. Features some black and white sequences. Commentary by Roger Newcombe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vincent Donovan and Department of Defence Public Relations

results.title: F-111 the first flight
results.creator_credit: Greg Parry and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
Trainee pilots and navigators undergo an intensive training course before they are allowed to operate the supersonic F-111 strike aircraft for the first time. Shows some of the students on their first flight in an F-111. Credits include: photography by Mal Lancaster; edited by Vincent Donovan; sound by Ron Townsend; commentated by Peter Gwynne and scripted by Greg Parry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Greg Parry and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations

results.title: North West Cape
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Sentinel”.
The joint U.S.-Australian naval communications station Harold E. Holt has long been controversial for its strategic role in the nuclear arms race and the tight security concerning its operations on Australian soil. This film, produced for the Australian Defence department, documents the military’s view on the naval station and the supposed rationale for its purpose and operation in Western Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence

results.title: Rescue 036
results.creator_credit: Greg Parry and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
The Army Aviation Centre at Oakey, Queensland, has more helicopter movements per year than any other airfield in Australia. Therefore the potential of aircraft accidents is great. The Army Aviation Corps have devised a crash rescue system designed to provide medical assistance to crash victims in the shortest possible time.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Greg Parry and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations

results.title: Solar oil
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
As Australian oil reserves recede, many scientists are turning to the sun for a solution in the looming energy crisis. In Australia, scientists employed by the Department of Defence have been encouraged by their research in a revolutionary form of oil - solar oil. The oil is obtained from a freshwater green alga (Botryococcus) which has the ability to store hydrocarbons direct from sunlight. Its special properties makes the alga an unusual subject of the plant world, and a possible key to energy alternatives. Photography by Phil Hobson, sound by Ron Townsend and narrated by Roger Newcombe.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations

results.title: Reaching for the rainbow
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Sentinel”.
A twenty-man specialist Australian Army Engineers Unit is helping the Papua New Guinea Government with road-building and major works projects in the remote Southern Highlands Province of central Papua New Guinea. No other credits available.

results.title: Anyone anything anywhere
results.creator_credit: Don Scheldrup, Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
Despite its low profile, the transport element of the Royal Australian Airforce is one of the largest air carriers in Australia. It has both national and international commitments and is capable of delivering anyone, or almost anything, anywhere in the world. Narrated by Peter Gwynne. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Scheldrup, Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations

results.title: Challenge of flight
results.creator_credit: Don Scheldrup, Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
Shows the tough and rigorous pilot training courses conducted by the Royal Australian Air Force at Point Cook in Victoria and at Pearce in Western Australia. Only fifty per cent of trainees pass the course.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Scheldrup, Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
